DOC.brief_summary: Endothelial dysfunction in resistance arteries in women after the menopause is important for the development of high blood pressure and cardiovascular disease
DOC.brief_title: Hormonal Replacement Therapy and Small Artery Function
DOC.detailed_description: We aim to study the effects of different hormone replacement therapies (HRT) on the function and morphology of resistance arteries, and to look for their mechanistic basis. We expect that HRT with estrogens or in combination with MPA may benefit the function of resistance arteries and may preserve the morphological integrity of endothelial cells by regulatory actions on the cytoskeleton.
DOC.criteria: All women had been amenorrheic for at least 1.5 year. Menopausal status was confirmed by a serum concentration of follicular stimulating hormone (FSH > 34 IU/ml) and estradiol (E2 <50 pmol/l). Cigarette smokers and women with: Hypertension Diabetes mellitus Clinical manifestations of arteriosclerosis (coronary heart disease, peripheral artery disease, or cerebrovascular disease) Venous thromboembolic disease Liver disorders Unexplained vaginal bleeding; and Personal or family history of breast cancer were excluded.
